To all girls interested in playing golf for the 2020-2021 season, please register via www.lincoln.8to18.com as soon as possible.

Golf is an excellent opportunity for scholarships and personal growth. It is a game that requires patience and perseverance; with consistent practice, players will notice a difference in their own game very quickly. Much of one’s ability to become a good golfer is determined by attitude and mental fortitude rather than physical strength or endurance -- this is what sets golf apart from other sports. It is recommended to have some prior experience however, all golfers are welcome. Being that golf is more of a mental game than physical, any girl with interest is encouraged to participate.

Girls are responsible for having their own clubs, balls, tees, shoes, and shorts/skorts; shorts and skorts must be appropriate length in the colors of khaki and black. Bags, polos, and rain jackets will be provided. Please contact Coach Cox with any questions via email at ccox@lchsrailers.org. Also, please fill out the form below:

https://forms.gle/8SwtFipybzeU8pT59

PRESS RELEASE

June 1, 2020

Lincoln Community High School is proud to announce the recipients of the Oliver C. and Roberta M. Hursh Memorial Scholarship Awards. Mr. and Mrs. Hursh did not have any children of their own, but education remained very important to them. They believed that society should encourage the real achievers among us. As has been done for the last nine years, and will be for the next thirteen years, the valedictorian and the salutatorian of Lincoln Community High School will each receive 25% of the annual trust earned income. This year’s recipients will each receive $24,788.02.

The 2020 Valedictorian is Sydney Worth. Sydney is the daughter of Darrin Worth and Tiffany Worth. Sydney plans to attend Southern Illinois University in Edwardsville.

The 2020 Salutatorian is Grace H. Lessen. Grace is the daughter of Eldon and Martha Lessen. Grace plans to attend Grace Christian University.

LCHS Driver Education Information:

PERMIT TESTING:
The LCHS Driver Education Department will be administering permit testing for students enrolled in first quarter classroom driver education. Testing will take place on Tuesday, June 16th. Information about the test, including testing times and procedural safeguards will be available at the high school when students return their materials to school next week. June 16th will be the only day permit testing will be offered this summer. Any student who does not pass the permit test on June 16th will have to wait until September to retake the test.

BEHIND-THE-WHEEL:
Currently the State of Illinois is not allowing behind-the-wheel instruction. Once behind-the- wheel instruction is allowed to resume, LCHS driver education instructors will be contacting students who were unable to complete 4th quarter BTW to schedule driving times. This will be done by birthday/permit order.

Illinois State Board of Education
May 19 at 11:21 AM ·

Pandemic EBT is a new benefit to help families buy food for their school age children who would normally receive free or reduced-priced meals at schools. Learn more at http://www.dhs.state.il.us/OneNetLibrary/27897/documents/Brochures/4980.pdf

Help us spread the word to Illinois families!

The easiest way to apply is online at https://abe.illinois.gov/abe/access/. Families currently receiving SNAP do not need to apply because these additional P-EBT benefits will be automatically loaded into Illinois LINK EBT accounts.

Families can also print out paper applications in English or Spanish and use mobile devices to scan or photograph their completed applications and email them to DHS.FCS.PEBT@illinois.gov or send them via regular mail to Central Scan Unit, PO Box 19138, Springfield, IL, 62763.

To assist families without internet access, schools can print out and distribute applications, then collect the completed paper applications and submit them (as a group) directly to IDHS for processing.

Parents and Guardians,
Please help us better serve our LCHS Students, Families and Community by filling out the following survey.
http://survey.5-essentials.org/illinois/survey/parent/

The State Board has long recognized that test scores alone do not provide a full picture of teaching and learning in any one school. Under recent legislation (Senate Bill 7, PERA), the State Board is now mandated on an annual basis to implement a learning conditions survey that will finally help paint that fuller picture. While this survey may help inform state policy and improvement initiatives, it is primarily intended to help local administrators identify strengths and weaknesses at the district and school level and target the necessary resources and interventions. Aggregated data from this anonymous survey will also be shared with parents and the general public on school report cards.

Congratulations to the LCHS Boys Soccer team for winning the East Peoria Soccer Tournament!
#MakeLincolnProud!
shared_text:
Lincoln Railers Boys Soccer
September 7, 2019 at 6:00 PM ·

After losing last night to Monmouth 1-0, our team thought we couldn’t win the tourney today. But this morning Monmouth lost to East Peoria and we were given new life. So after beating Eisenhower 9-0, Peoria Manual 8-0, and East Peoria 4-0, our boys found themselves as the East Peoria tournament champs for the second year in a row! In the 4 games this weekend, we outscored our opponents 21-1.

Named to the All Tournament team were AJ Beard, Payton Lanning, John Grover, and Garrett Slack.

Payton Lanning also picked up two shutouts on the day, making him the new career shutout record holder for Lincoln (with 16 and counting). The old record of 15 career shutouts was held by Brenton Saylor, who graduated in 2003. Congrats Payton!

Stats for today’s games: Goals were by Garrett Slack (4), Jace McIntosh (2), AJ Beard (1), Luke Morrow (2), Drew Bowman (2), and Zane Hartman (1). Assists were by Levi Mourning (2), AJ Beard (2), and one assist each for Ethan Bivin, Christopher Slack, John Grover, Jace McIntosh, and Luke Morrow.

LTEC tours the new Lincoln Police Department.

Police Chief Paul Adams conducted the tour that showed the students the training room and work areas. Chief Adams went over several subjects including the hiring process for officers, training requirements, and expectations. Students got to see how evidence handled and how suspects are processed and temporarily detained. Lincolnland Technical Education Center is a Career and Technical Education School housed at Lincoln Community High School that services Logan, Mason, and Menard Counties.
